intro: Sarcinula calderae, commonly known as the volcanic lichen, is a unique lichen species that thrives in extreme volcanic environments. It is a symbiotic composite of a fungus and a green alga, forming a composite organism capable of surviving in high-temperature and nutrient-poor conditions. The plant's structure consists of a dense, crust-like thallus that adheres tightly to volcanic rock surfaces. It plays a crucial role in the ecological succession of volcanic soils by contributing to soil formation and nutrient cycling. Due to its specialized adaptations, Sarcinula calderae is often used as an indicator of volcanic activity and environmental stability.
